vers in pencil: [C. Garabedian]
text:
Known for his exuberant and quirky figuration, California artist Charles Garabedian draws on mythological sources, biblical narratives, and popular fiction for his subjects, which typically explore psychological and sexual conflict between men and women. 

In this lithograph, Garabedien depicts the murder of a vampire, presumably Count Dracula, a character introduced by Irish author Bram Stoker in his 1897 Gothic horror novel Dracula. In Stoker's novel, Dracula is killed with a bowie knife, but later vampire stories tell of a wooden stake driven through the heart as the only effective means to kill a vampire. As the sun rises on the scene of death, a nude woman, perhaps one of Dracula's brides, calmly stands aside the casket that holds the dead vampire, a bloody stake protruding from his chest. Justice served'
title: The Vampire
